intro: Viola domestica var. communis, commonly known as the common violet, is a herbaceous perennial plant belonging to the Violaceae family. It typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, featuring heart-shaped leaves with a velvety texture and deep purple flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant is native to Europe and parts of Asia but has been naturalized in many regions around the world. It thrives in moist, well-drained soil and partial to full shade, making it a popular choice for woodland gardens. Its flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance.
